item.title: Why Don't More Languages Offer Flow Typing?
item.description: A brief survey of where flow typing does and doesn't fit, and when it may play a role in other languages.

item.title: Emulating the Lambda Calculus in TypeScript's Type System
item.description: We show that the TypeScript type system can emulate the lambda calculus, thereby providing a proof that the type system is Turing-complete.

item.title: Type Inference for Sound and Complete Flow Typing
item.description: We design a type inference algorithm for the FT calculus of "Sound and Complete Flow Typing with Unions, Intersections, and Negations" (Pearce 2012), proving that it infers minimal types where they are expressible and infers all minimal user-typable types.

item.title: Strictly Annotated: A Pretty-Printer With Support for Annotations
item.description: We present an extension of Lindig's Strictly Prettier (2000) pretty-printer with support for harmoniously formatting a document and arbitrary annotations attached to its terms.

item.title: A Flying Tour of Kan Extensions
item.description: A half-hour, flying tour of Kan extensions with examples and applications in other mathematics.

item.title: Representability, Coproducts, and Reflective Subcategories
item.description: Write-ups of interesting problems from Riehl's Category Theory in Context, sections 4.5 and 4.6.

item.title: A Simple Language With Flow Typing
item.description: We discuss a simple language and type system that provides for flow typing with records and union types. We also present an extension that generalizes to near-arbitrary narrowing of types at the expense of greater runtime costs.

item.title: Hot Code Reloading, with libc or in the browser
item.description: A small framework for writing programs with support for hot code reloading. Discusses runtimes that execute machine code or JavaScript in the browser.

item.title: Pattern Matching With a Typechecker
item.description: Solving problems without leaving the TypeScript type system.

item.title: Impact vs Innovation & Industry vs Academia
item.description: In popular industry, I often see discontinuities between 'impactful' and 'innovative' work. I describe how these discontinuities arise, and what we can do about them.
